briefing.opening: Hello everyone. We will now begin the climate briefing for February 19, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Severe Impacts and Increasing Risks of Climate Change
sections.content: Today's news reported severe risks caused by climate change simultaneously both domestically and internationally. Domestically, 'wildfire risk days' have tripled over the past 45 years, raising concerns about climate-fueled wildfires, with criticism that carbon neutrality alone may not be enough to prevent them [3, 4, 10]. Internationally, direct impacts are spreading, including an increase in bacterial infections among beachgoers on the U.S. East Coast, heatwaves and droughts causing divisions in border regions, and a report stating that buildings must adapt more quickly to climate change [42, 45, 46]. Furthermore, warnings continued that climate change could create 'insurance deserts,' cause mental health issues like 'eco-anxiety,' and lead to the slowdown of local ecosystems and nature [52, 53, 62, 64]. In California, avalanche risks remain high after a skier's death, while an experiment at the University of Sydney released a video suggesting that future heatwaves will be an unbearable experience for humans, further highlighting the reality of the climate crisis [71, 72].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Domestic and International Carbon Neutrality Efforts and Policy Implementation
sections.content: Amidst these crises, various efforts to achieve carbon neutrality are actively underway both domestically and internationally. Domestically, Seoul's Dobong-gu received the highest rating for four consecutive years in climate crisis response, and several local governments, including Cheongsong-gun, Jeonju-si, and Jinju-si, are fully committed to carbon neutrality, water management, and fine dust reduction [1, 5, 7, 12, 15, 16, 26]. Notably, Gimcheon-si and Gimhae-si are recruiting participants for the automobile carbon neutrality points system and providing incentives to practicing drivers, while Busan-si opened its 'Our Neighborhood ESG Center' and Dongdaemun-gu launched a carbon neutrality 'One Team,' all encouraging community participation [13, 18, 19, 20, 21]. Internationally, CDP recognized Pyxus's efforts in climate change and forestry, and Tuvalu is finding hope in climate change response through its transition to a 'digital nation' [56, 59]. China's carbon dioxide emissions are also stagnating or decreasing, and Ma Jun noted that Chinese coal power generation is no longer viable due to cheaper renewable energy, signaling positive changes [73, 74].

sections.title: ğŸ“° Accelerating Energy Transition and Policy Challenges
sections.content: Energy transition remains a core task in responding to the climate crisis, with ongoing discussions. Domestically, renewable energy generated at the Daebul Industrial Complex is slated for direct supply to resident companies, and Microsoft has committed to securing 100% renewable energy for its AI data centers' power demands [28, 29, 32, 34]. Korea Midland Power (KOMIPO) has made a decisive move to expand 'K-Renewable Energy' by participating in a 3.4 trillion won offshore wind power project, and the K-shipbuilding industry is also expanding its portfolio into wind power, indicating growing investment in the renewable energy sector [30, 33]. However, important opinions have been put forth, suggesting that pursuing only 'cheap electricity' is not the best approach for achieving carbon neutrality; instead, securing grid stability, establishing a rational power mix, and prioritizing social discourse are essential [8, 9, 11, 22]. This highlights the importance of not only technical and economic aspects but also social consensus in the energy transition process.

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Change Response and Conflicts
sections.content: In the international community, various movements surrounding climate change response are emerging, alongside patterns of conflict. The United States has expressed dissent in its search for a balance between energy security and climate change response, instructing the International Energy Agency (IEA) to reduce its focus on climate change and warning Western energy watchdogs of withdrawal if they do not abandon their 'net-zero focus' [37, 75]. Meanwhile, TotalEnergies faces a significant trial in France concerning climate change, demonstrating increasing international pressure on corporate climate responsibility [38, 48, 49, 50, 54, 58, 67]. Concurrently, a bill has been introduced in Vermont to mandate climate change education in schools, and the Yale Program on Climate Change Communication and the World Council of Churches are making efforts to raise climate change awareness through 'The Six Americas of Global Warming' and a Lenten campaign, respectively [40, 47, 63]. Furthermore, messages on climate change and animal protection are planned for delivery at the 2026 Winter Olympics closing ceremony, and interest and discussion on climate change continue in various fields, including research to find clues about beluga whales' climate change resilience [2, 41, 43].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has once again reminded us of the various threats posed by climate change, the multifaceted domestic and international efforts to counter them, and the importance of energy transition and international cooperation. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.original_title: Avalanche risks remain high in California after deaths of skiers
articles.description: Forecasters predict more snow in Sierra Nevada mountains as climate crisis increases threat of dangerous conditions. Avalanche risks remain high in the Sierra Nevada mountains of northern California this week, following the deadliest snowslide the region has seen in modern times. The climate crisis has set the stage for more dangerous conditions, with sharper swings between dry periods and severe storms, according to experts, who have long warned that extremes will amplify as the world warms. Conti

summary.outlook: Forecasters predict more snow in the Sierra Nevada mountains, and the climate crisis is expected to increase the threat of dangerous conditions.
